Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Melissa Nicole Thaw of the University of Nevada, Las Vegas to conduct a research project, entitled "Mechanisms of nutrient transport to Lake Taihu," during the summer of 2012 at Hohai University in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. The host scientist is Dr. Zhongbo Yu.

The intellectual merit of the research project comes from understanding how nitrogen and phosphorous are transported to Lake Taihu through groundwater, the air and by attaching to fine sediment. High levels of nitrogen and phosphorous have led a poisonous form of algae to bloom and pollute Lake Taihu. In the past, Lake Taihu has provided water to as many as 30 million people. It is important to understand how nutrients are transported to lakes because the occurrence and severity of these types of algae blooms are increasing around the world.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past two decades, an increase of nutrients to Lake Taihu, China has resulted in hyper-eutrophication and the production of cyanobacterial blooms, severely impacting drinking water for millions of people. While many past studies have focused on how surface water transports nutrients to the lake, this study characterized the concentrations of nutrients in different media, including rainwater, soil and groundwater from two different watersheds. This research improves our understanding of how pollution impacts drinking water sources.

The two watersheds examined varied in overall land use, and agricultural sites within each watershed varied by crop type and growing method. Samples were collected from the Meilin watershed, a mix of forest and agricultural land and the Zhangjiagang watershed, which consisted of industrial, urban and agricultural lands. Samples included soils, ground water, surface water and rain water. Soils from each site were characterized by aggregate size class and analyzed for total nitrogen and total phosphorus. Rainwater, groundwater and surface water samples were analyzed for nitrogen and phosphorus.

The PI was trained on Hohai University procedures for collected soil and water samples in the field and nutrient analysis in the laboratory. Relationships with research professors and students were both established and improved to enable future research collaboration. Cultural exchange and relationships established through this research project resulted in improved understanding between U.S. and Chinese researchers.
